channel.title: Histories - Digg
channel.description: Histories on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: The First Airplane To Fly In England Was Absolutely Ridiculous Looking
item.description: Where America had the Wright Brothers and their powered flight in 1903, our British pals celebrate Horatio Phillips and his imaginatively-named Flying Machine of 1907.

item.title: The Real Story Behind That Viral Photo Of President Johnson During The Vietnam War
item.description: It's an iconic image, but the photo is being taken out of context.

item.title: The King Who Became A Pirate
item.description: When King Erik VII of Denmark was forced from the throne, he did the only thing any self-respecting descendent of Vikings could: He joined the warriors of the sea and hit right back at his enemies.

item.title: The Complicated Truths Of Dr. Dre's 'The Chronic'
item.description: No rap album has quite the mythology attached to it — as a game changer, a king maker, a genre expander. But legends aren't exactly fact.

item.title: The Forgotten Tiger King Of Harlem
item.description: Antoine Yates spent three years living peacefully inside his NYC apartment with his 'roommate' — a 450-pound Siberian tiger named Ming. Until that is, Ming's animal instincts kicked in, and he mauled Yates in the middle of their kitchen.

item.title: Cool Photos Show Lifestyle Of American Teens In The Late 1980s
item.description: The 1980s is the period of multi-style fashion, especially for young people in the United States.

item.title: We Asked A Classics Professor How To Train Like A Real-Life Roman Gladiator
item.description: There's no training manual handy. But art has left us some clues.

item.title: The Writer Of 'Demolition Man' On The Predictive Power Of His 1993 Movie
item.description: In this interview with "Demolition Man" writer Daniel Waters, he discusses the accidental coronavirus-era prescience of his 1993 action comedy starring Sylvester Stallone, Sandra Bullock and Wesley Snipes, from no-contact high fives to seashells.

item.title: How Morley Became The Cigarette Brand Of Choice For Hollywood
item.description: If you pay close attention to TV and movies, you'll begin to recognize a recurring cigarette brand.

item.title: The History Of The Hawaiian Shirt
item.description: From kitsch to cool, ride the waves of undulating popularity of a tropical fashion statement.

item.title: The Great Immunity Divide
item.description: When yellow fever swept through 19th-century New Orleans, immunity became so valuable, it was worth risking death for.

item.title: Unholy Anorexia
item.description: Medieval mystics starved the body to feed the soul. Understanding this perfectionist mindset could help treat anorexia today.

item.title: Tax Incentives And The Human Imagination
item.description: It would be interesting to look at locations of the American popular imagination, as seen in movies and TV, mapped against regional tax breaks for the film industry.

item.title: Lionel Messi's 73-Goal Season Was A Triumph — And A Disaster For Barcelona
item.description: Remembering Lionel Messi's wildest season ever.

item.title: Hollywood Casts A Very Flattering Light On Right-Wing White Women
item.description: In reimagining the conservative activist Phyllis Schlafly as a prestige-TV antihero, the new FX series "Mrs. America" overlooks some uncomfortable realities.

item.title: The Obscure, Forgotten Spanish Jeeps Of The 1960
item.description: Under the moniker VIASA, or Vehículos Industriales y Agrícolas, these European-born Jeeps weren't ever sold in North America, and one would be hard pressed to find one for sale on either side of the Atlantic.

item.title: The Woman Who Discovered The First Coronavirus
item.description: The woman who discovered the first human coronavirus was the daughter of a Scottish bus driver, who left school at 16.

item.title: Remembering The Time United Airlines Offered A Men-Only Flight
item.description: From 1953 through 1970, United offered men-only 'Executive flights' — something you might see on an episode of "Mad Men."

item.title: Here's Why Almost No Sitcoms Use Laugh Tracks Anymore
item.description: The laugh track was once ubiquitous in sitcoms — why is that no longer the case?

item.title: The CIA Tracked Down A Nazi And Scoured Museums To Build A Siren To Scare The Hell Out Of People
item.description: The CIA wanted a device similar to the siren the Nazis had used on their legendary Ju-87 Stuka dive bombers — and went to great lengths to get one.

item.title: Pandemics Have Destroyed Cities Before. Could They Do It Again?
item.description: Charles Kenny, author of a forthcoming book on pandemics, is cautiously optimistic that cities will prevail in the era of COVID-19 — but nothing is a given.

item.title: A Complete Timeline Of The Coronavirus Pandemic And US Response
item.description: In response to COVID-19, the US was slow to act at a time when each day of inaction mattered most. Here's a comprehensive timeline.

item.title: Paul McCartney's Handwritten Lyrics for 'Hey Jude' Just Sold for $910,000
item.description: McCartney wrote the song for John Lennon's son Julian after Lennon began his relationship with Yoko Ono.

item.title: The Most Popular Tech Gadget From The Year You Were Born
item.description: From the remote control to the Xbox, take a look at the inventions that changed our lives through history.

item.title: What We Can Learn From 1918 Influenza Diaries
item.description: These letters and journals offer insights on how to record one's thoughts amid a pandemic.
item.kicker: THE LAST SYLLABLES OF RECORDED TIME

item.title: The 1904 Olympic Marathon Was The Worst Race Ever Run
item.description: The 1904 St. Louis Olympics were the first held outside Europe. Which sounds great until you remember that it was 1904, and the direct center of this vast country wasn't the easiest place to get to. In fact, St. Louis was so remote that most countries didn't bother to make the trip.

item.title: How Jim Varney Overcame Failure To Become A Cult Movie Star
item.description: Joe Ramoni took a deep dive into the remarkable rise of Jim Varney — from failed actor to overnight sensation.

item.title: This Abandoned Site Was Once The 'City Of 1,001 Churches'
item.description: The capital of medieval Armenia, the city of Ani was a thriving center of trade and faith, survived by its haunting ruins.

item.title: Lockdowns Flatten The 'Economic Curve' Too
item.description: Cities that locked down faster in 1918 bounced back better.

item.title: The Surreal Sight Of Disinfecting Historic Sites
item.description: Unsung workers around the world on the front lines of the pandemic fight.

item.title: How Infectious Disease Defined The American Bathroom
item.description: Cholera and tuberculosis outbreaks transformed the design and technology of the home bathroom. Will Covid-19 inspire a new wave of hygiene innovation?

item.title: How Did England Get Its Bizarro Street Names?
item.description: For your consideration: "Gropecunt Lane."
item.kicker: A STREET BY ANY OTHER NAME...

item.title: The Saga Of Punkin' Donuts
item.description: How a doughnut-shop parking lot became a confluence of Chicago youth subcultures — and what killed it off.

item.title: Hong Kong At Night In The 1960s Through Amazing Color Photos
item.description: 1960s in Hong Kong continued with the development and expansion of manufacturing that began in the previous decade.These color photos were found by Martin Snelling.

item.title: Was Leisure Suit Larry Really An Accomplice In Early Banking Cyberattacks?
item.description: In the late 80s, Sierra's hokey horndog was connected to a major computer virus, and rumor had it that the publisher may have created it to punish pirates.

item.title: Why The Apollo 11 Astronauts Were Put Into Quarantine After Getting Back From The Moon
item.description: Scientists feared Apollo 11 crew members could've brought back deadly pathogens from the moon and were immediately put inside a mobile quarantine facility.

item.title: The People Who Profited Off The Trail Of Tears
item.description: The deportation of Native Americans westward in the 1830s was fueled by busy bankers and unchecked avarice.

item.title: Wipe Out: The Curious History Of Toilet Paper
item.description: Although it may seem like a product that we've always been reliant upon, toilet paper has not actually been around very long, and may not be as essential as we think it is. Instead, it's the product of very good marketing.

item.title: History's Deadliest Pandemics, From Ancient Rome To Modern America
item.description: History shows that past pandemics have reshaped societies in profound ways.

item.title: When The Government Banned PBR, Pabst Made Cheese Instead
item.description: Selling dairy products helped the brewery survive Prohibition.

item.title: The 'Fingerstache' Ruled The 00s, But Many Still Have to Live With It
item.description: The 90s had barbed wire armbands and lower back tribal designs, but the pseudo-ironic finger mustache was the most iconic ink of the aughts.

item.title: The Fascinating History Behind How London Split Up Into 32 Boroughs
item.description: Jay Foreman gives the intriguing backstory on how the current boroughs of London got delineated.
item.kicker: THE EAST END BOYS AND WEST END GIRLS

item.title: The Long History Behind The 5G Coronavirus Conspiracy Theory
item.description: "Before every pandemic of the last 150 years, there was a quantum leap in the electrification of the Earth."

item.title: How The Most Iconic Arcade Game Fonts Were Designed
item.description: There were a lot of challenges that had to be faced in creating some of the most well-known 8-bit arcade game fonts.

item.title: The Photographer Couple Who Turned Industrial Architecture Into Fine Art
item.description: Together, Hilla and Bernd Becher documented the disappearing markers of industry across Europe and North America, including factory buildings, gas tanks and silos.

item.title: The Truth About Isaac Newton's Productive Plague
item.description: The idea that the bubonic plague woke the brilliance in Newton is both wrong and misleading as a measure of how well we apply ourselves during our own plague spring.

item.title: A Comet May Have Destroyed This Paleolithic Village 12,800 Years Ago
item.description: Fragments of a comet likely hit Earth 12,800 years ago, and a little Paleolithic village in Syria might have suffered the impact.

item.title: How Epidemics Of The Past Changed The Way Americans Lived
item.description: Past public health crises inspired innovations in infrastructure, education, fundraising and civic debate

item.title: Cities That Went All In On Social Distancing In 1918 Emerged Stronger For It
item.description: They had lower mortality rates from the influenza pandemic. But their economies also appeared to fare better.

item.title: The Russian Plot To Take Over Hollywood
item.description: They wanted a spy at the center of the industry. He had bigger ambitions. The wild true story of wheeling and dealing double agent Boris Morros and the woman who became his nemesis.
